title-group.article-title: Effective Elastic Moduli of Spherical Particle Reinforced Composites Containing Imperfect Interfaces

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Fukuoka University, Fukuoka 814-0180, Japan
Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1593, USA

author-notes.corresp: *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. E-mail: kyanase@fukuoka-u.ac.jp

abstract.p: The effective elastic moduli of composite materials are investigated in the presence of imperfect interfaces between the inclusions and the matrix. The primary focus is on the spherical particle reinforced composites. By admitting the displacement jumps at the particle–matrix interface, the modified Eshelby inclusion problem is studied anew. To derive the modified Eshelby tensor, three approximate methods are presented and compared by emphasizing the existence of a unique solution and computational efficiency. Subsequently, the effective elastic stiffness tensor of the composite is formulated based on the proposed micromechanical framework and homogenization. Specifically, by incorporating imperfect interface, the modified versions of the Mori–Tanaka method, the self-consistent method, and the differential scheme are presented. By comparing these three methods, the effects of interfacial sliding and separation on the degradation (damage) of the effective elastic moduli of composites are analyzed and assessed. Finally, a critical aspect of the presented formulations is specifically addressed.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In his pioneering work, Eshelby (1957) solved the general problem of the elastic state of an inclusion with eigenstrain located within a distinct material. Eshelby’s work forms the theoretical backbone for analyzing many problems of interest in materials science, solid-state physics, and mechanics of composite materials. The major advantage of Eshelby’s approach is that it enables us to predict full multi-axial properties and responses of heterogeneous materials. In the literature, Eshelby’s approach has been extensively adopted to predict effective mechanical moduli of composites; see, for example, Hill (1965), Mori and Tanaka (1973), McLaughlin (1977), Weng (1984), Norris (1985), Ju and Chen (1994a, b, c), Ju and Zhang (1998, 2001), Ju and Sun (1999, 2001), Ju and Lee (2000, 2001), Sun and Ju (2001, 2004), Sun et al. (2003a,b), Liu et al. (2004, 2006), Lee and Ju (2007, 2008), Ju and Oh (2008), and Lin and Ju (2009).

In addition to properties of individual constitutive components (phases), the interface between the matrix and the inclusion plays a key role in controlling the overall properties of a composite. In the inclusion problems studied by Eshelby, the inclusions are assumed to be perfectly bonded to the matrix. However, in many engineering applications, the interfaces in those materials may not be perfectly bonded to the matrix. For instance, inhomogeneities in high strength steel can be easily debonded after a few cyclic loading. In polycrystals and granular materials, grain boundary sliding is a common phenomenon. Further, it is generally acknowledged that the detrimental effects of an inclusion on mechanical properties of steel are caused by the stress-raising effect or by weak bonding at the interface between the inclusion and the surrounding matrix (Grabulov et al., 2010). Therefore, the assumption of perfect bonding is inadequate for the description of the physical nature and mechanical behavior of the interface region. To tackle this problem, a micromechanics has been extensively employed to study the damage and failure of engineering materials. In particular, by using micromechanics, the effects of interfacial damage have been investigated to study mechanical behavior of composites (c.f., Zhao and Weng, 1997, 2002; Ju and Lee, 2001; Sun et al., 2003a; Zheng et al., 2003; Ju et al., 2006, 2008; Ju and Ko, 2008; Ju et al., 2009; Ju and Yanase, 2008, 2009, 2010).

Researchers have extensively studied the free-sliding and the linear-spring models. The free-sliding model allows for relative slip in the tangential direction of the inclusion; but a displacement jump in the normal direction at the interface is not permitted. Physically, the free-sliding model may represent grain boundary sliding in polycrystals, the behavior of precipitates at high temperature, or imperfectly bonded interfaces in composite materials. For instance, Ghahremani (1980), Mura and Furuhashi (1984), and Jasiuk et al. (1987) adopted the free-sliding model to analyze local elastic fields and the effective properties of materials. In the linear-spring model, the imperfection of interface is reflected mainly by the discontinuity of the displacement field across the interface. Therefore, the linear-spring model postulates that the traction is continuous across the interface but that the displacement field is discontinuous. The corresponding eigenstrain problem is termed the modified Eshelby inclusion problem (Qu and Cherkaoui, 2006). The linear-spring model has been commonly used to study the mechanical behaviors of composites (Aboudi, 1987; Hashin, 1991; Qu, 1993a, b; Gao, 1995; Zhong and Meguid, 1997; Duan et al., 2005; Lee and Pyo, 2007, 2008).

In the literature, the cohesive model has been a popular method to tackle the interfacial damage behaviors of various engineering materials. In general, the cohesive damage models consider the energy release in a cohesive fracture process zone to simulate the equivalent reduction of material properties. However, the energy dissipation process in cohesive fracture is much more complicated than a purely elastic fracture process. In addition, these models cannot be analytically solved even by approximate methods. On the other hand, though less rigorous, the use of linear-spring model is a simple and flexible approach to treat an imperfect interface with limited number of model parameters. The objective of this article is to investigate the effect of interfacial damage on effective elastic moduli of spherical particle reinforced composites based on the spring-interface model (Qu, 1993a, b; Qu and Cherkaoui, 2006). Moreover, based on micromechanics framework and homogenization, the micromechanical effective medium theories are reformulated in the presence of an imperfect interface. Finally, the effects of interfacial sliding and separation are systematically investigated in conjunction with the appropriate computational schemes.

sec.title: IMPERFECT INTERFACE
sec.p: For a perfect interface, the displacement and traction fields are continuous across the interface. The continuity of displacement and traction across the perfect interface can be described as: (1) (2)

where u iS+ and σ ijS+ are the values evaluated at the positive side of S, while u iS- and σ ijS- the values evaluated at the negative side of S. Furthermore, it is assumed that nj points to the positive side of S.

For quasi-static problems, the imperfection of the interface is characterized mainly by the discontinuity of a displacement field across the interface. Accordingly, the spring-interface model (Figure 1) dictates that only the traction is continuous across the interface: (3) Figure 1.
A schematic illustration of the spring interface model.

On the other hand, the displacement jump across the interface is assumed to be proportional to the traction vector. Hence, we postulate the following equation: (4) where the second-order tensor ηij represents the compliance of the interface. For simplicity, we assume that ηij is symmetric and positive definite. It is clear that ηij =0 corresponds to the perfectly bonded interface, while ηij → ∞ represents the completely debonded interface.

The physical significance of ηij can be exemplified by adopting the following form: (5) where δij is the Kronecker delta. By referring to Figure 2 associated with Equations (4) and (5), we obtain the following relations: (6) (7) Figure 2.
The normal and tangential displacements associated with the displacement jump. (a) The normal displacement, (b) The tangential displacement.
Namely, the constants α and β are related to the interfacial sliding and the interfacial separation, respectively. It is noted that material interpenetration may take place when β ≠ 0.

sec.title: APPROXIMATE SOLUTIONS FOR THE MODIFIED ESHELBY INCLUSION PROBLEM
sec.p: In this section, a brief summary of the modified Eshelby tensor derived with the iterative method (Qu, 1993b; Qu and Cherkaoui, 2006) is first presented for completeness. Subsequently, alternative computational schemes are proposed to derive the modified Eshelby tensor.

sec.title: The Iterative Method
sec.p: By admitting the displacement jump at the interface of inclusion, and after a lengthy derivation (Qu and Cherkaoui, 2006), the displacement field can be expressed as follows: (8)

Here, C ijkl 0 is the elastic stiffness of the surrounding matrix material, Gij∞ represents the Green function, and ɛ ij* signifies the eigenstrain. Further, S and Ω are the boundary and the volume of an inclusion, respectively.
Let us assume that the eigenstrain is uniform within Ω. Therefore, Equation (8) leads to: (9)
By changing the indices in Equation (9), one can obtain: (10) where: (11)
By making use of the interior-point Eshelby tensor or S tensor, Equation (10) can be rewritten as: (12) where: (13)

For a spherical inclusion, S is rendered as (Mura, 1987; Nemat-Nasser and Hori, 1993): (14) where ν0 is Poisson’s ratio of the surrounding matrix material. Since the eigenstrain is stress-free, Hooke’s law can be expressed as: (15)
By using Equations (14) and (15), we write Equation (12) as: (16)

To solve Equation (16), one may need to use an approximate method. For instance, by taking advantage of the iterative method, Equation (16) can be solved as: (17) for n = 1, 2\comma … N. For convenience, the initial value is set as: (18)
Hence, after the first iteration of Equation (17), we obtain: (19)
For simplicity, let us define: (20)
By utilizing Equation (20), Equation (19) takes the form: (21)

Here, Iijkl is the fourth-order identity tensor. The result of Equation (21) can be viewed as the modified Eshelby tensor with an imperfect interface. One significant feature of the modified Eshelby inclusion problem is that the strain within an ellipsoidal inclusion is no longer uniform despite the uniform eigenstrain.
For convenience, let us compute the homogenized Eshelby tensor within an inclusion domain: (22) where, for a spherical particle, we have: (23)
To carry out the integral, we consider the following operation (Equation (13)): (24) where: (25)
In Equation (25), the surface integral for the spherical inclusion can be expressed as (Ju and Chen, 1994b): (26)
Therefore, Equation (25) can be recast as: (27)
Further, by making use of the Voigt form, Equation (27) can be rendered as follows: (28) where: (29)
By using the tensorial notation, Equation (22) can be recast as: (30)
Finally, one can easily show that the iterative procedure results in the following equation: (31) with the initial guess or initial condition (Equation (14)): (32)
Apparently, when R = 0 in Equation (31), the modified Eshelby tensor can reduce to the Eshelby tensor with a perfect interface.

sec.title: The Decomposition Method
sec.p: By making use of the decomposition method (Wazwaz, 1997) associated with the average-strain tensor, Equation (16) can be rewritten as (Equation (13)): (33)
Therefore, by adopting the tensorial notation, the decomposition method results in: (34)
Consequently, we obtain: (35)
Similar to Equation (31), when R in Equations (34) and (35), the modified Eshelby tensor reduces to the Eshelby tensor with a perfect interface.

sec.title: The Direct Computation Method
sec.p: Invoking the average-strain tensor, we express Equation (16) as: (36)
Accordingly, by using the tensorial notation, Equation (36) can be recast as (Equation (13)): (37)
On the basis of Equation (37), the average-strain can be explicitly expressed as: (38)
Similar to Equation (31), by setting R} = 0 in Equation (38), the modified Eshelby tensor Ŝ reduces to the Eshelby tensor S with a perfect interface.

sec.title: Comparisons of the Modified Eshelby Tensors
sec.p:
To investigate the computational aspects and capabilities of the approximate methods presented in the previous sections, comparisons are made for the modified Eshelby tensors computed by the respective methods. When interfacial damage is relatively small, a couple of iterations are sufficient to obtain accurate calculation for the modified Eshelby tensor (Figure 3). Further, when the amount of damage increases, several iterations are required to achieve convergence (Figure 4). Interestingly, irrespective of the amount of damage, the direct computation method exhibits excellent results in comparison with the other two methods. However, when a relatively large amount of damage is considered, the three methods can no longer render identical results, as exhibited in Figure 5. In particular, the calculations by the iterative method and the decomposition method tend to blow up as the number of computations increases. By contrast, it appears that the direct computation method is stable in computing the modified Eshelby tensor. However, since a unique solution cannot be obtained when the damage is relatively large, the validity of the direct computation method should be further examined. Figure 3.
The computations for the modified Eshelby tensor with a relatively small amount of damage. (a) The 1111 component, (b) The 2323 component. Figure 4.
The computations for the modified Eshelby tensor with an intermediate amount of damage. (a) The 1111 component, (b) The 2323 component. Figure 5.
The modified Eshelby tensor with a relatively large amount of damage. (a) The 1111 component, (b) The 2323component.

Figure 6 shows the variations of the modified Eshelby tensor. As revealed, the direct computation becomes singular at a certain point. Based on Equation (38), the modified Eshelby tensor can be represented as: (39) where: (40) (41) with: (42) Figure 6.
The variation of the modified Eshelby tensor (1111 component) with α′ and β′.
As a special case, by setting α = β = 0, one can easily show that (Equation (14)): (43)
According to Equations (40) and (41), it is apparent that the modified Eshelby tensor becomes singular when one of the following conditions is satisfied: (44) (45)
Therefore, owing to Equations (44) and (45), we postulate the bounds as follows: (46)

On the basis of Equation (46), Figure 7 exhibits the bounds of ά and β′ for some engineering materials. As expected, each material has its own unique bounds for ά and β′. Figure 7.
The bounds of α′ and β′ for the engineering materials. (a) Aluminum matrix (E0 = 75.0 × 103, MPa, ν0 = 0.33), (b) Titanium matrix (E0 = 113.7 × 103 MPa, ν0 = 0.3), (c) Epoxy matrix (E0 = 3.0 × 103 MPa, ν0=0.4).

In the following section, despite the aforementioned disadvantage, we employ the direct computation method in the micromechanical formulation to take advantage of its explicit expression (Equation (38)). Therefore, we set the following equation: (47)

sec.title: The Modified Mori–Tanaka Method
sec.p: In this section, the modified Mori–Tanaka method (Qu and Cherkaoui, 2006) is reviewed for the sake of completeness and further derivations. Let us consider a composite material containing randomly located spherical inclusions in a matrix. In addition, we assume that interfaces between the inclusions and the matrix are not perfectly bonded. The average stress within a representative volume element (RVE) of a composite is defined as: (48) where: (49) is the average stress in the rth phase.

On the other hand, by considering the displacement jump at the interface, the average strain over the RVE of a composite is rendered as (Qu, 1993b; Qu and Cherkaoui, 2006): (50) where S(r) is the surface of Ω(r) and

the average strain within the rth phase: (51)
By making use of Equation (4), the surface integral in Equation (50) becomes: (52)

Strictly speaking, the computation of stresses at the interface is a difficult problem. Thus, by taking advantage of average internal stress of inclusion, an ad hoc approximation for Equation (52) is formulated as: (53)
Therefore, by substituting Equation (53) into Equation (50), the average strain can be rewritten as: (54)
For the Mori–Tanaka method, the equivalence equation is expressed as: (55) where: (56)
Accordingly, from Equation (55), the eigenstrain can be obtained as follows: (57)
Further, the average strain within the rth phase can be written as: (58) where: (59)
Therefore, the average stress for the rth phase is rendered as: (60)
Moreover, by making use of Equation (58), Equation (54) can be recast as: (61)

Finally, based on Equation (48), the average stress of an RVE reads: (62) here C* represents the effective elastic stiffness tensor of a composite. For the modified Mori–Tanaka method, the following property holds (Qu, 1993a; Qu and Cherkaoui, 2006): (63) where D* signifies the effective compliance tensor of a composite.

sec.title: The Modified Self-Consistent Method
sec.p: In conjunction with the self-consistent method, Eshelby’s equivalence equation leads to: (64) where: (65)

In Equation (64), the modified Eshelby tensor should be computed based on the effective stiffness of a composite. Accordingly, by making use of Equation (64), the eigenstrain within the rth phase can be expressed as: (66)
By using Equation (66), the average strain within the rth phase can be written as follows: (67)
Further, by considering the average strain of a composite, we arrive at (Equation (54)): (68)
By arranging Equation (68), we have: (69)
Finally, by using Equations (67) and (69), the average stress of a composite takes the form: (70)
In Equation (70), C* signifies the effective stiffness tensor of a composite based on the self-consistent method.
Based on Equation (67), the stress–strain relation within the rth phase leads to the following equation: (71)
In regard to the average strain, Equation (54) can be expressed as: (72)
Further, by making use of Equation (70), we obtain the following relation: (73)
By substituting Equations (71) and (73) into Equation (72), we arrive at: (74)
To check the consistency of the modified self-consistent method, we apply the following operation for Equation (70): (75)
By rearranging the above equation, we have: (76)
By comparing Equations (74) and (76), we can show that: (77)
Therefore, the modified self-consistent method is literally self-consistent.

Since T SC(r) (Equation (70)) needs to be computed based on the unknown elastic stiffness C*, the iterative method is employed to carry out the computation for T SC(r) and C*. By considering the two-phase composite, we write Equations (38), (67), and (70) as: (78) (79) (80)
For the initial condition or guess, by using the elastic stiffness of the matrix material, we set: (81)
By performing the proposed iterative method, we can obtain T SC(1) and C* as follows: (82)

To demonstrate the computational capability of the proposed method, the components of the TSC tensor are plotted in Figure 8. By performing a few iterations, each component of the TSC tensor successfully converges to a certain value. Accordingly, one can apply the proposed iterative method to compute the effective stiffness of a composite in conjunction with the modified self-consistent method. Figure 8.
The convergence of the TSC tensor components. (a) The 1111 component, (b) The 2323 component.

sec.title: The Modified Differential Scheme
sec.p: The basic concept of the differential scheme is to view the overall composite as a sequence of the dilute composite (Christensen, 1990). Accordingly, by adding a small amount of inclusions Δ ф (1)}, we assume a newly obtained composite as a homogeneous matrix. For example, using Equation (80), we write the effective stiffness as (Qu and Cherkaoui, 2006): (83) where: (84) with: (85)
By using the above three equations, the iterative calculations need to be carried out until the desired volume fraction is obtained.

Figure 9 demonstrates the relationship between the number of discretizations and the convergence of the effective stiffness. As illustrated, the modified differential scheme works successfully to calculate the effective stiffness of a composite in the presence of interfacial damage. It is noted that, compared with the modified self-consistent method (Figure 8), a relatively large number of computations is necessary to achieve convergence here. Figure 9.
The convergence of the C* tensor components. (a) The 1111 component, (b) The 2323 component.

sec.title: NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS AND DISCUSSIONS
sec.p:
Based on the presented micromechanical formulations, several numerical simulations are performed to investigate the effects of an imperfect interface. In essence, based on the single-inclusion problem, the effective medium theories account only for the average effect of all other inclusions (i.e. far-field interactions). However, in order to predict the deformation responses of composites with high volume fractions, the individual or the near-field interactions among the inclusions should be properly considered (Ju and Chen, 1994b; Ju and Zhang, 1998; Lin and Ju, 2009; Ju and Yanase, 2010a, b). Therefore, by using the modified counterparts of the effective medium theories, a moderate volume fraction (ф = 0.3) is considered for the numerical simulations here. Figures 10 and 11 show the effects of α′ and β′ (Equation (42)) on the effective elastic moduli of a T6-A356/SiC composite. As expected, the respective formulations compute slightly different values for the effective elastic moduli. However, the elast increasing amount of interfacial damage. associated with an increasing amount of interfacial damage. Moreover, it is noticed that the parameter β′ (or the extent of interfacial separation, Figure 11), has more pronounced effect on the effective Young’s modulus and the effective bulk modulus compared with the parameter α′ (or the extent of interfacial sliding, Figure 10). As pointed out by Qu (1993a), for the modified Mori–Tanaka method, the parameter α′ does not affect the effective bulk modulus. Similarly, for the modified self-consistent method and the modified differential scheme, our calculations manifest that the parameter α′ has a negligibly small effect on the effective bulk modulus (Figure 10). Figure 10.
The effects of α′ upon the effective elastic moduli. (a) The effective Young’s modulus, (b) The effective shear modulus, (c) The effective bulk modulus. Figure 11.
The effects of β′ on the effective elastic moduli. (a) The effective Young’s modulus, (b) The effective shear modulus, (c) The effective bulk modulus.

For multiphase systems, the Mori–Tanaka method may not yield diagonally symmetric elasticity tensors. Since the composite with an imperfect interface can be classified as a multiphase system, the symmetry of elasticity tensor is a concern. In his original calculation, Qu (1993a) obtained the weak asymmetry of elasticity stiffness based on the modified Mori–Tanaka method. By contrast, according to our computations, not only the modified Mori–Tanaka method, but also the other two methods yield the symmetry of effective elastic stiffness tensor.

In this study, relatively small values of α′ and β′ are employed to investigate the effect of imperfect interface. However, as demonstrated by Figure 12, the elastic constant becomes singular as one increases the value of β′. As discussed in the previous section, to properly use the proposed micromechanical formulations, one carefully needs to set the upper bounds for α′ and β′ (Equation (46), Figure 7). Finally, as an extension of this study, an investigation for the effect of imperfect interface on the overall plastic yielding of a composite will be performed in a forthcoming paper. Figure 12.
The variation of the effective Young’s modulus computed by the modified Mori–Tanaka method.

sec.title: CONCLUDING REMARKS
sec.p: Based on the spring interface model, the effective medium theories are reformulated in the presence of interfacial separation and sliding between the spherical inclusion and the surrounding matrix. To derive the modified Eshelby tensor, three approximate methods are presented and compared. Moreover, by making use of the modified Eshelby tensor, the effective medium theories are reformulated by admitting the imperfect interfaces. As demonstrated, the unique combination of α′ and β′ leads to a distinct amount of degradation in the effective stiffness for a composite.

fn.p: Figures 1–12 appear in color online: http://ijd.sagepub.com
